heading_s: Google celebrates the Hour of Code 2013 with this tribute to Grace Hopper, one of the very first computer programmers.
Celebrities from all walks of life, including Ashton Kutcher, Shakira, Mark Zuckerberg, Angela Bassett, Dwight Howard, and more, kick off the 2013 campaign.
short_heading_s: The Hour of Code is here

heading_s: For the second year in a row, President Obama kicks off Computer Science Education Week by asking students to learn an Hour of Code.
Eddy Cue, Apple’s SVP of Internet Software and Services: “Education is part of Apple’s DNA and we believe this is a great way to inspire kids to discover technology.”
short_heading_s: Apple supports the Hour of Code on its homepage

heading_s: “Every girl deserves to take part in creating the technology that'll change our world, and change who runs it.”
short_heading_s: Nobel Peace Prize winner Malala Yousafzai challenges girls to do the Hour of Code
FOX Business: 29 Companies Join Forces for the Hour of Code
TIME: Frozen’s Anna and Elsa ‘Let It Code’ to Close the Tech Gender Gap

heading_s: President Obama is the first president to write a line of code, hosting a historic Hour of Code for students at the White House.
Senator Cory Booker meets with students from Newark, New Jersey and inspires them to keep learning skills that'll prepare them for 21st-century futures.
short_heading_s: Epic Hour of Code selfie with Cory Booker

heading_s: Pro basketball legend Dikembe Mutombo does the Hour of Code with students in Brooklyn, New York.
From Shanghai to Sydney to Brussels to New York City.
short_heading_s: Apple hosts Hour of Code workshops in every store worldwide

heading_s: “It was amazing to see everybody engage and excel." - Charlie Mayer, Operations & Investor Relations, Opower
Goldman Sachs employees organize code-themed career days at their offices in Dallas & Salt Lake City.
Over 800 HP employees volunteer, introduce new learning tools in over 90 schools, and host over 50 events globally and nationally.
Accenture employees participate in 186 cities across 56 countries and pledge to complete nearly 8,000 Hours of Code!
AMEX employees present a Code.org $10,000 award to Nova Eisenhower Elementary.
Over 1,466 GoDaddy employees volunteered and tried an Hour of Code around the world.
AT&T sets new records by volunteering in schools, giving inspirational talks, and mentoring students across the country and even in the UK.
Employees across IAC brands joined Hour of Code for the first time
Expedia mobilizes volunteers in Vegas & Seattle
Over 400 Salesforce employees volunteered globally, including teaming up with 17 schools in San Francisco and 4 in Oakland.
Verizon employees participate in more than 15 schools, including the Verizon Innovative Learning Schools, where every student is provided a tablet to inspire learning anytime, anywhere.
Amazon’s VP of Consumer Business & Code.org Board member, Jeff Wilke joined the Code.org team to present a $10,000 prize to Rainer Elementary School in WA.
The Hour of Code 2015 is announced with a brand new video, and a goal to reach 100,000 events.
NFL player Earl Thomas joins Washington Governor Jay Inslee and middle school students for an Hour of Code.
short_heading_s: An Hour of Code with a Seahawk

heading_s: Code.org, Disney and Star Wars launch Hour of Code "build-your-own-game" tutorial to broaden computer science participation. The lesson features Leia and Rey from Star Wars: The Force Awakens.
short_heading_s: Hour of Code features Star Wars: The Force Awakens
Wired: Star Wars Characters Will Now Teach Your Kids To Code

heading_s: Microsoft and Code.org team up for “Minecraft” Hour of Code tutorial that aims to introduce millions of youth to the creativity of computer science
Sheryl Sandberg, Karlie Kloss, Jessica Alba, and inspiring women in tech share their thoughts on changing the world.
The Borough President of Brooklyn, New York City challenges Chicago on who can get more schools to do the Hour of Code.
The Windy City is in for the friendly competition, asking every single school to join the movement.
short_heading_s: Chicago steps up the the challenge

heading_s: Students at 198,000 events nearly every country in the world — from France to Pakistan to Brazil to Cambodia to the US — begin the Hour of Code 2015.
#HourOfCode gets a special Twitter emoji and the hashtags trends in the United States and abroad.

short_heading_s: Snapchat releases an Hour of Code filter

heading_s: Additional Disney VoluntEARS support the campaign worldwide.
short_heading_s: Disney hosts a kickoff in Los Angeles

heading_s: Ahead of the release of Star Wars: The Force Awakens, Star Wars characters join the Hour of Code movement.
The actress, activist, and entrepreneur hosted an Hour of Code with the entire staff at The Honest Company

heading_s: She asks her fans to try it "because it's cool and important."

heading_s: Luna Ruiz, 17, joins Code.org founder Hadi Partovi. She tells the crowd: "Working in tech is about collaboration and playing your part."

Hour of Code takes over Times Square

heading_s: 12th grade computer science student Amina Dualeh joins us to ring the Opening Bell at Nasdaq, celebrating the week's worldwide Hour of Code event.
short_heading_s: Hour of Code rings the NASDAQ stock market opening bell

heading_s: UK's Prime Minister hosts students at 10 Downing Street. "In this digital age, coding matters, which is why initiatives such as the Hour of Code are so important."
short_heading_s: David Cameron does the Hour of Code

heading_s: Surprising everyone — even store employees — Apple's CEO joined an Hour of Code workshop and called for fundamental changes in education.
short_heading_s: Tim Cook crashes an Hour of Code

heading_s: "By learning to code today, you're already getting a head start on taking over the world." — Dona Sarkar
This girl tried our "Minecraft" Hour of Code tutorial and goes through every emotion you feel on your coding journey, with an amazing finish.

Google Director of Education Maggie Johnson moderated a panel where Four students from around New York City spoke about how they got into computer science, and shared their advice for both their classmates and leading tech companies.

heading_s: After an epic battle, 80% of Brooklyn schools did the Hour of Code vs. 60% in Chicago. Not bad!
